Fig. 1 XRD patterns of CeO2, Co3O4-CeO2 and Co3O4 catalysts: (○) Co3O4. Fig. 2 FE-SEM images of (a) CeO2, (b) Co3O4 and (c) Co3O4-CeO2. Fig. 3 SEM and EDX mapping analysis of Co3O4-CeO2. Fig. 4 TEM images of Co3O4-CeO2. Fig. 5 O2-TPD profiles for catalysts. Fig. 6 H2-TPR profiles for catalysts. Fig. 7 NO oxidation as a function of temperature (feed: 0.05% NO+5% O2; space velocity ≈150,000h−1). Fig. 8 TOF at temperature 250 and 300°C (feed: 0.05% NO+5% O2; space velocity ≈150,000h−1). Catalysts Experimental conditions Catalytic activity Limitations Ref. 1 2.5wt% Pt on SiO2 500ppm NO, 5% O2, 5% H2O, and balance N2,150lN/h; * SV=187,500h−1 ≈75% at 300°C Noble metal usage [19]. a 2 20wt% Co/SiO2 150ppm NO, 8%H2O, 10% O2 and balance N2; SV=100,000h−1 ≈69% at 300°C NO conc. used was quite low [16] 3 1.5wt% Pt -0.3wt% Pd on SiO2/monolith 600ppm NO, 5% O2 and balance N2; SV=30,000h−1 ≈75% at 300°C Noble metals usage, low SV [20] 4 9.5wt% Co/CeO2 b 500ppm NO, 5vol% O2 and balance N2; W/F of 0.045gs/ml; * SV=80,000h−1 ≈70% at 270°C Low thermal stability, moderate SV [13] 5 9.6wt% Co/CeO2 c 500ppm NO, 5vol% O2 and balance N2; W/F of 0.045gs/ml; * SV=80,000h−1 ≈30% at 270°C Poor activity [13] 6 25% Co3O4/MPS d 500ppm NO, 10vol% O2 and balance N2; SV=12,000h−1 82% at 300°C Very low SV [12] 7 La0.8Ce0.2CoO3 800ppm NO, 8% O2, and balance He, W/F: 0.096g s/ml; * SV=37,500h−1 ≈80% at 300°C Good activity but very low SV [10] 8 La0.9Sr0.1CoO3/monolith 400ppm NO, 8 vol% O2 and balance N2; SV=30,000h−1 ≈86% at 300°C Good activity but the SV was quite low [14] 9 Pt-Pd/Al2O3 200ppm NO, 10% O2, 5% H2O and balance N2; SV=100,000h−1 ≈43% at 400°C Noble metals usage and the con. of NO was low [21] 10 1.5wt% Pt on TiO2 500ppm NO, 8% O2, 5% H2O and balance N2; SV=100,000h−1 ≈25% at 350°C Noble metals usage & still low activity [22] 11 LaMnO3 400ppm NO, 8% O2 and balance N2; SV=30,000h−1 ≈63% at 350°C Quite low SV [23] 12 1wt% Pt/Al2O3 500ppm NO, 8% O2 and balance Ar; High NO oxidation catalytic activity on non-noble metal based cobalt-ceria catalyst for diesel soot oxidation Suresh Kumar Megarajan a S. Rayalu a Y. Teraoka b Nitin Labhsetwar a ⁎ a CSIR-National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (CSIR-NEERI), Nehru Marg, Nagpur 440020, India CSIR-National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (CSIR-NEERI) Nehru Marg Nagpur 440020 India b Department of Energy and Material Sciences, Faculty of Engineering Sciences, Kyushu University, Kasuga, Fukuoka 816-8580, Japan Department of Energy and Material Sciences, Faculty of Engineering Sciences, Kyushu University Kasuga Fukuoka 816-8580 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 712 2249753; fax: +91 712 2249753. Graphical abstract In this study, we have explored commercial ceria, commercial cobalt oxide (Co3O4) and a laboratory synthesized nano-ceria supported cobalt oxide (Co3O4) for catalytic NO oxidation, which is an important reaction for soot oxidation in diesel particulate filters (DPF), used for vehicle exhaust emissions control. Ceria supported cobalt oxide has been synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation method, and shows high catalytic activity for NO oxidation at moderate temperature. The catalytic activity is even comparable to reported noble metal based NO oxidation catalysts, and could be mainly due to the high dispersion of Co3O4 nanoparticles on ceria support with enhanced catalyst support interaction. This has also resulted in improved redox properties of Co3O4-ceria catalyst. Keywords Cobalt oxide Ceria Catalyst Catalysis NO oxidation 1 Introduction Control of soot/particulate matter (PM) emissions from diesel vehicles has been one the most important and challenging problems since last few decades. Diesel exhaust contains excessive oxygen due to the high air-fuel ratio combustion condition. The most effective technology till date is the Diesel particulate Filter (DPF), in which the collected soot is oxidized by NO2 derived from the oxidation of NO available with diesel exhaust. Considering that NO is predominantly present in diesel exhaust and also that the exhaust temperature is quite low for diesel vehicles, it is important to oxidize NO to NO2 at a temperature of about 175–300°C [1–8]. The noble metal, i.e. Pt and Pd based catalysts have only been reported to find practical applications for this reaction. As also in the case of three-way catalysts, high cost and limited availability of noble metals have necessitated the search for potential non-noble metal based catalysts, which has become one of the thrust areas of current catalysis research. There are a number of non-noble metal based catalysts reported including those zeolites, perovskites, supported oxides, spinels and mixed oxides for NO oxidation [9–16]. However, many of these studies have shown certain limitations with respect to their potential for practical applications. Wen et al. studied series of La1−x Ce x CoO3 perovskite oxide catalysts for nitrogen monoxide oxidation, and reported approximately 80% conversion on La0.8Ce0.2CoO3 at 300 °C under the W/F of 0.096gs/ml. They have also compared the activity of perovskite catalyst with pure Co3O4 and CeO2 [10]. Kim et al. also investigated the perovskite supported honeycomb catalysts for NO oxidation using 400ppm NO and at space velocity of 30,000h−1, and reported about 86% conversion at about 300°C on La0.9Sr0.1CoO3 [14]. From the literature, it is known that cobalt based perovskite type catalysts demonstrate good activity for NO oxidation and therefore show potential as substitute for Pt based NO oxidation catalysts. However, low surface area is the major limitation of perovskite type catalysts as most of the studies are reported using low space velocity conditions, quite unrealistic for diesel exhaust applications. Considering high catalytic activity, Co3O4 based catalysts deserve further R&D attention, however, reports on supported Co3O4 catalysts are relatively less. TiO2 and SiO2 supported Co3O4 catalysts were studied for NO oxidation by Irfan et al. [16]. They reported maximum of 69% conversion on Co3O4/SiO2 at 300°C with high space velocity condition, however, the concentration of NO used was 150ppm, which is quite low. They concluded that the more oxidizing ability towards NO is the major reason for better activity of Co based catalysts [16]. Huang et al. studied cobalt oxide supported on mesoporous silica (surface area 1119 m2/g) for NO oxidation, and achieved about 82% NO conversion at 300°C, which is very good activity and quite comparable to noble metal catalysts. However, the space velocity used (12,000h−1) was very low, while use of mesoporous silica is still not considered for practical application due to stability requirements. They also observed that high temperature calcination leads to rapid decrease in catalytic activity and sintering occurs at a temperature as low as about 300°C [12]. Recently, Kim et al. studied NO oxidation on supported cobalt oxide synthesized by conventional wet impregnation method using various supports including CeO2, SiO2, ZrO2, TiO2 and SiO2, and reported that CeO2 supported catalyst exhibits better activity. They reported approximately 70% conversion at about 270°C on Co-ceria (S BET =230m2/g) under the W/F of 0.045gs/ml and found that surface area of CeO2 plays an important role on catalytic activity [13]. From this background, it is clear that cobalt oxide based catalysts are potential candidate for NO oxidation, and a prospective substitute for platinum group metal compositions. The catalytic activity of cobalt oxide can be substantially improved by using high surface area supports with good thermal stability. Improved synthesis methods leading to homogeneous and high dispersion of Co on supports is an important aspect to achieve the improved NO oxidation activity at higher space velocities. This paper describes the synthesis of (Co3O4) cobalt oxide catalyst supported on ceria nanoparticles using a relatively simple incipient wet impregnation method leading to high and uniform dispersion of Co-oxide on ceria support. Catalytic evaluations towards NO oxidation were carried out under the very high space velocity of ≈150,000h−1, mainly to explore its catalytic activity under realistic conditions to possibly assess its potential for practical applications. The catalytic activity of Co-CeO2 was compared with bare commercial Co3O4 and CeO2 catalysts. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and temperature programmed desorption (TPD) studies were carried out to explain the redox properties and correlation with catalytic activity of the present catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Commercial ceria (JRC-CEO-3, supplied by Catalysis Society of Japan), commercial Co3O4 (Wako, Japan) and laboratory grade Co (NO3).6H2O (Chameleon Reagents, Japan) were used directly without any purification. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis 10wt% Co-CeO2 was prepared by using incipient wetness impregnation method. An aqueous solution of cobalt nitrate (equal to half amount of total inter particle pore volume of support) was added to ceria support, and thoroughly mixed until the entire volume was soaked without any tearing drops. The resulting mass thus obtained was dried in oven at 110°C for 3h. The above process was repeated for several times to obtain desired loading. Finally, the precursor thus obtained was homogenized and calcined at 400°C for 4h in a muffle furnace. Prior to the synthesis, ceria was preheated at 650°C for 5h in order to ensure the thermal stability of support for catalytic evaluations. 2.3 Catalyst characterization All commercial and synthesized catalysts have been characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (RINT2200, Rigaku) operated at 40kV and 40mA with a monochromator using Cu Kα radiation. The specific surface area and pore volume of catalysts were analysed by following standard nitrogen method using BEL-SORP Mini, BEL Japan instrument. The FE-SEM (Field Emission Scanning Electron Microphotograph) investigations were carried out using JEOL (JSM-6340F) instrument to study the morphology of catalysts. High resolution SEM images were obtained using ZEISS ULTRA PLUS FESEM machine, while TEM investigations were carried out using FEI Tecnai T20, instrument. Samples were prepared by dispersing the powder in ethanol and then dropping 1–2 drops on aluminum gird (for SEM) and copper grid (for TEM). O2-TPD and H2-TPR analysis were performed using a BEL-CAT, BEL Japan instrument, equipped with a TCD detector. A fixed bed of granules of catalyst was placed in a quartz tube; prior to each TPD run, the catalyst was heated up to 400°C under the air flow (30ml/min). After 30min of isothermal heating at this temperature, the catalyst was cooled to 40°C under the same air flow. Helium was then fed to the reactor at 10-ml/min-flow rate and was kept flowing for 1h at room temperature in order to purge out any excess oxygen. The catalyst was then heated up to 400°C at the constant heating rate of 10°C/min under the same helium flow, and O2 desorbed during the heating was determined. For H2-TPR experiments, the catalyst was pretreated under a flow of helium (30ml/min) at 200°C for 30min and cooled to 40°C under the same flow. The reduction of catalyst was followed by heating the catalyst up to 600°C at constant heating rate of 10°C/min under the 5% H2–N2 flow, and consumption of H2 during the heating was determined by using a TCD detector of a gas chromatograph. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurement The catalytic NO oxidation was carried out in a fixed bed, steady state type gas reactor. Granules of catalysts (0.1g) were packed in a quartz reactor for catalytic run and temperature of the reactor was maintained by using a PID controlled furnace. Prior to the catalytic activity test, the catalysts were pretreated at 200°C for 2h in a flow of nitrogen for surface cleaning. The total flow rate of 150 SCCM of high purity (0.05% NO+5% O2) gases was measured by mass flow controllers (HORIBA, Japan). After the catalyst attained steady state over a period of 1h at each temperature, the effluent gas was analysed by NO x analyser (Shimadzu-NOA 7000) for 60–90min at each temperature to attain constant value. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 shows the X-ray powder diffraction patterns for CeO2, Co3O4 and 10wt% Co incorporated CeO2, and clearly reveals the expected phases with good crystallinity. The X-ray diffraction pattern of Co incorporated CeO2 catalyst was compared with standard JCPDS cards, which confirms the formation of Co3O4 phase on cubic ceria support (JCPDS-07 2155 and 024210). The lattice parameters as well as cell volume calculated for both bare and cobalt promoted catalysts (now referred as Co3O4-CeO2) are shown in Table 1 . A lowering of pore volume of ceria was observed, which is obviously due to incorporation of cobalt oxide. This also suggests dispersion of cobalt oxide in the pores of ceria by using present method of synthesis. The crystallite size for all the catalysts was also calculated from diffraction data using Debye-Scherrer formula. As shown in Table 1, the crystallite sizes for CeO2 before and after incorporation of Co-oxide were observed to be almost same (around 117–121Ǻ). The crystallite size for commercial Co3O4 was 611Ǻ, while the crystallite size for Co3O4 (2θ =36.84) phase present in Co3O4-CeO2 catalyst was 140Ǻ. This further substantiates the formation of nano-crystalline Co3O4 in the pores of ceria, which was achieved through a simple incipient wet impregnation method, due to homogeneous dispersion of precursor Co solution less than the pore volume of ceria in the pores of the ceria. The FE-SEM images of commercial ceria, Co3O4 and synthesized catalysts are shown in Fig. 2(a–c). The FE-SEM microphotograph (Fig. 2b) shows typical hexagonal shaped particles for commercial cobalt oxide catalyst. The similar micrograph images were obtained for both ceria and cobalt promoted ceria catalysts, which confirms that the morphology remains intact even after 10wt% of cobalt loading. The SEM image and EDX mapping data for Co3O4-CeO2 are shown in Fig. 3 , which suggest nano-structure of Co3O4-CeO2 as well as good dispersion of Co3O4 on ceria. TEM images are shown in Fig. 4 , which also suggest the nano-crystalline nature of CeO2 support as well as the nanoparticles of Co3O4 (dark particles). Both SEM and TEM analysis of Co3O4-CeO2 therefore suggest dispersion of cobalt oxide on nano-crystalline ceria support, which leads to strong Co3O4-CeO2 interaction. The BET surface area and pore volume results are shown in Table 1. The surface area for bare ceria was 72m2/g, while appreciable decrease was observed in case of cobalt promoted ceria catalyst. The similar effect was observed in pore volume values as well. The pore volume for bare ceria and Co3O4-CeO2 was 0.22 and 0.16cm3/g, respectively. This moderate reduction in surface area as well as pore volume is due to the dispersion of cobalt oxides in the inter particle pores of the ceria support, which further suggest possible formation of nano-size cobalt oxide. Crystallite size results also clearly corroborate the formation of nano-size cobalt oxide crystals. The O2-TPD and H2-TPR studies were carried out to understand the oxygen non-stoichiometry and redox properties of catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the O2-TPD profiles for bare ceria, Co3O4 and Co3O4-CeO2 catalysts. For CeO2, a broad oxygen desorption peak starts around 210°C, which is due to the surface oxygen desorption. In case of Co3O4 and Co3O4-CeO2 catalysts, two different oxygen desorption peaks were observed. Oxygen desorption at lower temperature corresponds to surface oxygen, while the higher temperature desorption can be assigned to the lattice oxygen desorption, due to reduction of metal oxidation state. For commercial Co3O4, the surface oxygen desorption was observed at 240–400°C, while this was shifted to lower temperature in the range of 180–340°C for Co3O4-CeO2 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3, the lattice oxygen desorption was shifted to lower temperature (375°C) for Co3O4-CeO2, while this was observed above 400°C for unsupported Co3O4. This improved redox properties of Co3O4-CeO2 catalyst should be due to the strong interaction between Co3O4 and ceria support, which leads to weakening of Co–O bond [17,18]. Improved synthesis of Co3O4 in the inter particle pores of ceria improves this catalyst-support interaction and in this way, the preparation method can affect the redox properties of cobalt-ceria type catalysts. H2-TPR results for bare ceria, Co3O4 and Co3O4-CeO2 are shown in Fig. 6 . For CeO2, a hydrogen consumption peak was observed at (300–580°C), which is due to the reduction of surface capping oxygen as well as the CeO2 surface reduction. For Co3O4, a broad peak was observed at about 270–550°C, which should be due to combined reduction of Co3O4 to CoO followed by CoO to metallic Co. In case of Co3O4-CeO2, well defined three peaks reduction profile was observed. Hydrogen consumption at lower temperature (130–160°C) was due to the reduction of surface oxygen. The second TPR peak at temperature 220–330°C corresponds to the combined reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and surface capping oxygen of CeO2 support, while the high temperature (330–525°C) reduction peak should be due to the reduction of CoO to Co as well as the bulk CeO2 to Ce2O3. In this way, the TPR analysis clearly demonstrates the lowering of reduction temperature and overall increased H2 consumption. This further substantiates the improved reducibility of Co3O4-ceria catalyst, due to the improved catalyst-support interaction, as also discussed in previous section. Quantitative hydrogen consumption data for all the catalysts are given in Table 2 . Both TPD and TPR studies therefore inferred the improved redox properties of Co3O4 after dispersion on ceria support. Considering the typical behaviour of NO oxidation and specific low temperature requirement for diesel emission control, the NO oxidation activity in a temperature window of 200–400°C is of utmost importance for catalytic soot oxidation applications. The catalytic activity results (Fig. 7 ) inferred that high NO oxidation was achieved for Co3O4-CeO2 catalyst, showing 80% NO conversion to NO2 at 300°C. This is quite high NO conversion under the high space velocity conditions and considering the fact that not even small amount of platinum group metals are used as promoter. The present Co3O4-CeO2 catalyst shows more than 60% NO oxidation at 250°C and even higher activity at 350°C (after equilibrium as shown in Fig. 7) at a space velocity of as high as 150,000h−1. It is important that a catalyst should be active in a wide range of temperature for diesel emission control related reactions. To the best of our knowledge, such efficient catalytic NO oxidation at high space velocity of 150,000h−1 is not reported for a non-noble metal based catalyst. This good activity is also of especial significance considering the moderate surface area of ceria, i.e. ≈70m2/g, which is relatively lower as compared to those reported catalyst supports, and also considering the fact that the ceria support was preheated at 650°C in view of high thermal stability requirements. Fig. 8 shows the TOF (turn over frequency) for NO oxidation reaction at 250 and 300°C. TOF was calculated as millimoles of NO converted per gram of catalyst per unit time. Maximum 0.027mmol NO was converted per gram of catalyst when Co3O4-CeO2 shows over 80% conversion at 285°C, whereas Co3O4 and CeO2 catalysts convert a maximum of 0.011 and 0.005mmol of NO, respectively at the same temperature. This high NO oxidation activity of ceria supported cobalt oxide, can be explained through improved redox properties as well as dispersion of cobalt oxide particles on ceria support, which leads to improved catalyst–support interaction. Ceria can be easily coated on commercially available cordierite honeycomb supports and is an essential constituent of three-way catalysts. Therefore, compatibility of present catalyst on these supports is not an issue for possible practical applications. A comparative overview of catalytic activity of present Co3O4-CeO2 catalyst in comparison of other reported catalysts including those noble metal based compositions reported for NO oxidation is presented in Table 3 . This analysis clearly infers the prospective of present Co3O4-CeO2 based catalyst composition for NO oxidation, as the catalytic activity is comparable to that with Pt group metal counterparts. Use of a simple incipient wet impregnation method is also important in practical point of view, as some of the synthesis methods reported for other non-noble metal based catalysts are difficult for bulk catalyst processing. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, ceria supported cobalt oxide catalyst was prepared by a simple incipient wetness impregnation method, which offers uniform dispersion of Co3O4 on ceria support. The catalytic activity of bare ceria, Co3O4 and ceria supported Co3O4 was studied for NO oxidation reaction under the conditions of practical relevance, i.e. high NO concentration with high space velocity. The ceria supported cobalt oxide shows high catalytic activity for NO oxidation reaction in the temperature range of interest for diesel exhaust applications. This high NO oxidation activity of supported catalyst can be explained with the improved redox properties through Co3O4-ceria interaction, as well as uniform dispersion of Co oxide, which is achieved by means of simple incipient wetness impregnation method. Nano-crystalline structure of Co3O4-CeO2 and uniform dispersion of Co3O4 on CeO2 was demonstrated by SEM-EDX and TEM studies. As evidenced from the cited literature, the present catalyst shows exceptionally high NO oxidation activity considering the conditions used and its non-noble based composition. The improved redox properties of present Co3O4-CeO2 catalyst can be explained by oxygen TPD and hydrogen TPR results. Cobalt content optimization and catalyst preparation on commercial honeycomb support are in progress on this potential catalyst. This work also opens the possibility of other cobalt based catalysts for their application in NO oxidation related reaction, considering the great demand for minimization and even replacement of noble metal catalyst components. The present work also highlights the importance of synthesis method for Co3O4-CeO2 catalyst to achieve effective catalyst-support interaction leading to improved redox properties. Acknowledgements This work was carried out under the DST-JSPS bilateral project No. GAP-1962, of CSIR-NEERI, India and Kyushu University, Japan. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we have explored commercial ceria, commercial cobalt oxide (Co3O4) and a laboratory synthesized nano-ceria supported cobalt oxide (Co3O4) for catalytic NO oxidation, which is an important reaction for soot oxidation in diesel particulate filters (DPF), used for vehicle exhaust emissions control. Ceria supported cobalt oxide has been synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation method, and shows high catalytic activity for NO oxidation at moderate temperature. The catalytic activity is even comparable to reported noble metal based NO oxidation catalysts, and could be mainly due to the high dispersion of Co3O4 nanoparticles on ceria support with enhanced catalyst support interaction. This has also resulted in improved redox properties of Co3O4-ceria catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: High NO oxidation catalytic activity on non-noble metal based cobalt-ceria catalyst for diesel soot oxidation
